articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
Hi!
I am a student at the University of Toronto. I’m in the Data Science Specialist Program.
My strengths are mostly conceptual/abstract topics such as programming, math, and statistics. I am great at learning and applying ideas. For example, at my internship, I’m using my data science skills to lead an analytics project using python.
In my spare time, I’m working with Convolutional and Recurrent neural networks, and trying to do small projects to learn new concepts. I hope to work on data science research in the future. More on that soon!
My other skills include web scraping, SQL, data analysis/models in python.

            Bio
            I’m Kevin Wang!
            I study data science at the University of Toronto. I draw and mess around with neural networks.
            I don’t have any career goals. My only goal is to understand data science research papers, like this one, to be able to participate in challenges like the ImageNet challenge and to be able to come up with my own research topics and have fun. If becoming a data scientist will help me in this journey, I will work my hardest to become one.
            
            
            Experience
            — | Jr Data Scientist/Analyst | May 2022-Aug 2022
            U of T ISSC | Web Scraping and APIs workshop | July 2021
            STEM Fellowship | Google Analytics Team | September 2019 - October 2020
            
            
            Projects
            League of Legends Prediction Project Created a classification model that predicts match outcomes of the popular video game, League of Legends, with ~82% accuracy.
            Data is hand-collected and carefully processed. Writeup can be found here
            Edworthy Web Scraping Project
            Uses discord and web scraping to notify me when my favorite locations are empty. Uses BeautifulSoup and discord.py in python.
            
            
            
            Education
            University of Toronto | Toronto, ON GPA 3.93/4.00(would be 4.0 if I didn’t fail my essay on Michael Buble’s “Feeling Good”)
            Data Science Specialist | September 2020 - May 2024

articles.title: Projects
articles.description: Selected projects in R and python.
articles.contents:
Contents
Tensorflow Blog Series
Gradient Descent Visualization
League of Legends Web Scraping Project(V2)
Course Review System Project
Edworthy web scraping project
House prices linear regression project

Tensorflow Blog Series
Small tensorflow articles/tutorials on medium.com
Found here
Gradient Descent Visualization
Just a cool visualization of gradient descent.
found here
League of Legends Web Scraping Project(V2)
Created a classification model to predict match outcomes of the popular game, League of Legends, with ~82% accuracy.
Web scraped the popular site, LeagueOfGraphs.com, and collected data from the official Riot Games API.
Used python libraries such as numpy, pandas, matplotlib and sklearn to process and visualize the data, and to fit a model.
Used a Random Forest Classifier to create a model with 82% Accuracy. More details about exploratory data analysis, visualization and model creation can be found here

github repository
Course Review System Project
Command line tool that allows users to login, view, comment on and rate courses. Built in Java, this application follows SOLID principles and Clean Architecture, and uses software design patterns to implement many features. This was the final project for my Intro to Software Design class at U of T.

github repository
Edworthy web scraping project
A bot that looks at google search results and tells me when parks are empty, so that I can go on walks. Uses BeautifulSoup and discord.py in python.

Google results(left) gets translated to a Bot notification(right)
github repository
House prices linear regression project
Predicting house prices in Ames, Iowa. This was a data science challenge on Kaggle. Used data cleaning and linear regression techniques to score in the top 15 percent of participants.
github repository
